meaning: An approximation of a general function using a linear function.
The principal part of the change in a function y = f(x) with respect to changes in the independent variable.
The largest and smallest value of the function, either within a given range (local or relative extrema), or on the entire domain (global or absolute extrema).
Any of the two furthest points on a line segment.
Absolute extrema refer to the absolute minimums and maximums. Local/relative extrema refer to the relative minimums and maximums.
If a function is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval.
A point in the domain of the function where the function is either not differentiable or the derivative is equal to zero.
Connects the average rate of change of a function to its derivative.
The first derivative test analyzes functions using their first derivatives to find extremum points. The second derivative test determines local extrema of a function under certain conditions.
When the slope continually increases, the function is concave upward. When the slope continually decreases, the function is concave downward.
Relates to the rate of change of a function's derivative.
A point on the graph of a function at which the concavity changes.
An expression involving two functions whose limit cannot be determined solely from the limits of the individual functions.
Provides a technique to evaluate limits of indeterminate forms.
A function that repeats its values at regular intervals.
Maximizing or minimizing some function relative to some set.
An antiderivative is a function that reverses what the derivative does.
A mathematical object that can be interpreted as an area or a generalization of area.
The definite integral is the limit and summation to find the net area between a function and the x-axis. An indefinite integral takes the antiderivative of another function.
The integral is well defined.
